prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Scutterling's Song

'Twas gribbly in the tunnel deep,
Where misted walls did weep and seep,
When forth the slithy Scutterling crept
To hear its echoes twist and leap.

"Whiffleoo!" its voice did bound,
Ping-ponging off the tiles around,
Till every chirp and warbled cry
Became a whirlsome, lurpling sound.

The concrete curves did multiply
Each squealish note up toward the sky,
Till seven voices seemed like twenty,
And twenty seemed to never die.

Then homeward did the creature prance,
Its echoes caught in sonic dance,
While motorways above did roar,
And leave the tunnel to its trance.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Mizzlewump's Morning

'Twas glizzy and the slopeywokes
Did swish and shimmer in the breeze;
All misty were the oakeychokes,
And fogmice crept with ease.

"Beware the Mizzlewump, my friend!
The teeth that bite, the claws that catch!
Keep close your whiffling fogproof-blend,
And mind the mistlatch!"

He took his vorpal scope in hand,
Long time the wraithing foe he sought—
Then rested by the tumtum band,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in muffled thought he stood,
The Mizzlewump, with eyes aflame,
Came whistling through the pearly wood,
And gurgled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
His crystalline blade went snicker-snap!
The fog beast fled, the morning brew
Poured sunshine in his lap.

"Oh frabjous day! The fog is slain!
The glizzy morn turns bright and fair!"
He chortled in his misty gain,
While dawn danced in the air.

'Twas glizzy and the slopeywokes
Did swish and shimmer in the breeze;
All misty were the oakeychokes,
And fogmice crept with ease.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Whiffleswoon

'Twas glimspering, and the memorave
Did twist and tumble in my mind
The same-but-different moments gave
Their echoes of some prior kind.

Beware the Whiffleswoon, my friend!
That slinks through time's repeated dance,
With memorflux and temporbend
It leads you in a cosmic trance.

The scene unfolds—I've been right here!
Each motion traced in duplicate,
The slithy seconds disappear
While past and present replicate.

And as I stand in dazzled thought,
The Whiffleswoon slides softly by,
This moment that I've surely caught
Before—or was it all a lie?

'Twas glimspering, and the memorave
Did twist and tumble in my mind,
Till all the moments that it gave
Left déjà vu's sweet maze behind.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Sneathing Path

Beware the trodden sneathingway,
Where grasses bend and muckles sway!
The proper path's too far to stay,
So shortcut-seekers disobey.

Through whiffling weeds and trampled ground,
The footsteps daily pound and pound,
Till earth grows bare where paths are found,
And sneatherlings go round and round.

The walkways planned in clean-cut lines
Now yield to curves through soft designs,
While gardeners wail with frabjous signs:
"Please keep off grass!" - but none confines.

And so the sneather-treaders win,
Their footfall-wisdom etched within
The earth's own hide through thick and thin,
A path where none had ever been!

O sneathingway! O desire trail!
Your truth cuts through each planned detail,
While urban planners grump and wail,
The people's feet shall yet prevail!
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Meetingbeast

'Twas glumbling in the fluorglow bright
When suitclad workers, row by row,
Did pitch and preach with slidedeck might
While Zoomcalls came and go.

"Beware the Meetingbeast, my friend!
The endless talks, the pointless share—
Beware the Notetake-drone, and shun
The frumious Chair-to-spare!"

They took their laptop blades in hand,
Long time the PowerPoint they slayed—
Then rested by the whiteboard wall,
And stood awhile dismayed.

And as in KPI-ish thought they stood,
The Meetingbeast, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the conference wood,
And scheduled as it came!

One-two! One-two! Their minds grew numb,
As agenda points went snicker-snack!
They left it dead, and with its head,
They went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Meetingbeast?
Come to thy cube, productive child!
Oh frabjous day! Let's end the fray!"
They coffee-smiled with wild.

'Twas glumbling in the fluorglow bright
When suitclad workers, row by row,
Did pitch and preach with slidedeck might
While Zoomcalls came and go.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Melodious Whimblesome Room

"Beware the tungling keys, my friend,
The strings that snap, the drums that bend!
The crashing cymbsker most of all,
The whiffling flutes that screech and fall!"

Through shingled shelves of musibooks,
Past brazen horns with twisted crooks,
The young musrician danced with glee
To find what songs there might yet be.

The whistleharp sang brilligwise,
While violumpets touched the skies,
The thumpering bass did roundly boom
In that most splendiferous room!

"And hast thou tamed the tungling keys?
Come dance the songwhirl in the breeze!
O frabjous day! The music flows!"
Through shimmerlight the rhythm glows.

In windowed walls of warm buzzum,
Where notes like starlings dive and hum,
The melodaire swirls sweet and clean,
The finest room there's ever been!

poem:
The Snazzlegrasp's Map

'Twas gribbly in the cartograph,
Where squiggles turned and swurled.
The Snazzlegrasp did chortle-laugh
As compass-points unfurled.

Through mounty-peaks and swishling seas,
Past towns of tumbletone,
The pathways stretched like branching trees
To places yet unknown.

"Beware the lurching Wanderbeast!"
The parchment seemed to say,
"Who prowls the margins, West to East,
And steals lost souls away!"

With inkstained claws and gleaming eyes,
The Snazzlegrasp did trace
Each whimpled road that snaked and flies
Through time and measured space.

Now legends dance in maplight fair,
Where scales grow old and bend,
And in that gribbly cartograph,
Adventure has no end.

poem:
The Lurking of Layover Bay

'Twas brimpling in the terminal night,
The travelers glumped and groaned away,
All mopsy were the fluorites,
And gate calls did delay.

"Beware the Layover Bay, my friend!
The endless hours, the luggage sprawl!
Beware the Snackbox-vend, and shun
The dreaded Delayed-Call!"

They took their Boarding Pass in hand,
Long time the next flight's gate they sought—
So rested they by Coffee-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in weary wait they slumped,
The Layover Bay, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the charging ports,
And grumbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
Their patience went snicker-snack!
They found their gate, and with their fate,
Went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the waiting time?
Come to thy home, O wandrous one!
O frabjous day! Hip-hip-hooray!"
They chortled in their fun.

'Twas brimpling in the terminal night,
The travelers skipped and soared away,
All zippy past the fluorites,
Home-bound from Layover Bay.

poem:
The Phosphor-Wraith

'Twas glaring bright, the pixelglow
Did burn and simmer on the screen;
All ghostly were the logotypes,
And the taskbar sheen.

"Beware the Phosphor-Wraith, my friend!
The colors that decay and stay,
The persistent bright, the image-bent,
The shadows that won't sway!"

He took his power button strong
And pressed it firm with might and main,
But still upon the darkened glass
The spectres did remain.

And there, burnt deep in LCD,
The Phosphor-Wraith, with luminous trace,
Left watermarks all smearily
Upon the screen's bright face.

"O frabjous woe! O bitter sight!"
The user wailed in deep dismay,
As permanent as permafrost,
The ghost refused to fade away.

'Twas glaring bright, the pixelglow
Did burn and simmer on the screen;
All ghostly were the logotypes,
And the taskbar sheen.

poem:
The Brutterbeast

'Twas sizzling and the foamy fat
Did whirr and bubble in the pan;
All milky were the solids that
Through golden waves began to span.

"Beware the Brutterbeast, my friend!
The nose that sniffs, the specs that brown!
Beware the burncliff edge, and tend
Lest all your work goes tumbling down!"

They took their watchful spoon in hand:
Long time the toasty flecks they tracked—
Then rested they by cooling stand,
And stood awhile in thought, intact.

And, as in nutsome thought they stood,
The Brutterbeast, with notes of prawn,
Came wafting through the kitchen-wood,
And burbled as it spawned!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The patient spatula went whisk!
They caught the browning through and through
And bottled it, all brisk!

"And hast thou tamed the Brutterbeast?
Come taste thy victory, dear child!
O frabjous sauce! Perfect for feast!"
They drizzled and they smiled.

'Twas sizzling and the foamy fat
Did settle golden in its jar;
All hazelnutty, rich at that,
And ready near and far.

The Snizzlewort

When snurgling vines did twist and creep,
The Snizzlewort with rattled tail
Came slinking through the deepmost deep.

Through tangleweeds and mumbly moss,
Its scritchy claws did softly prowl,
All flexsome was its midnight gloss,
Beneath the lurming midnight howl.

O'er root and stone it scritched along,
Its jellied eyes aglow with might,
While all around the creepful song
Of shadows danced in pale moonlight.

Beware the creeping Snizzlewort,
When moonmist makes the shadows bend,
For in its wake, so goes the sort
Of dreams that never seem to end.

poem:
The Splendorous Awl

Beware the pointy awl, my dear,
Its pricksome tip so bright and clear!
The handle smooth, the metal spire,
All whiptious in its fierce desire!

I took my leathrous bits in hand,
My stitchsome projects freshly planned.
The awl went snicker-snap, and through
Each hole it punched so crisp and true!

And as I worked with splendid skill,
The awl did pierce with joyous thrill,
Until at last my work was done,
Oh frabjous day! The crafting won!

"And hast thou slain the craftless fear?
Come to my arms, my stitching dear!"
Oh glorious tool! Oh perfect awl!
The finest piercer of them all!

poem:
The Meddlefox's Warning

Beware the meddlefox, my dear,
Who snicks and snides through others' lives,
With pokey paws and listeny ear,
Through windows, doors, and secret hives!

The interfering beast did prowl,
All snuffling in the private-time,
With whisperations, foul and fowl,
Through matters none of his to climb.

But forth went brave young Silence-Jack,
With quiet-sword and tippy-feet,
To send the nosey creature back
Where secret things and peace could meet.

O frabjous day! The meddlefox
Has scampered from our peaceful glen,
Now locked away in shame-proof box,
Our private lives are ours again!

poem:
The Sciencewock Fair

Beware, young minds, the sciencewock fair,
Where bubblous brews and sparklets glare!
Avoid the slithy chemistry,
And voltmeters that zang with glee.

"Take care! Take care!" the teachers cry,
"The explodious things might splatter high!"
But forth the brave experimench went,
With hypothesis and data bent.

And as in labwork thought they stood,
The hypothests, with findings good,
Came whiffling through the data maze,
And burbled forth in winning ways!

O frabjous day! The medals shine!
The ribbons blue, the glory fine!
The sciencewock was conquered true,
By brilliant minds both fresh and new!

And now they smile, their projects done,
The science battle fairly won,
While teachers beam with pride so rare,
At champions of the sciencewock fair!

The Printwock's Lament

Did spin and sprocket in the tray;

The teeth that catch, the sheets that bind!

He freed the sheets, and with a "Whew!"
He pulled the paper back.

Oh frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"

The Vorpal Déjà-View

When whispering memrants slipped away,
All timey-wimey in the night,

poem:
The Snarlewing's Lair

'Twas gloomdark in the stage-side wings,
Where proptrels stood in dusty rows,
The Snarlewing with velvet rings
Did grimpet 'round the shadow-flows.

The curtain-whisps all slifted there,
Where stagehands tip-toed, quick and sly,
While rope-chains dangled in the air
And scene-drops loomed up mountain-high.

The rafters creaked their whispering tune
As dancers waited, breath held fast,
Till spotlights, like a silver moon,
Would call them forth to dance at last.

But deep within those darkened folds,
Where timewords never dare to sing,
The dustmotes dance their tales untold
Beneath the watch of Snarlewing.
label: low

The Brillig Butter

The Quibblefix

'Twas snazzling, and the whimblefeet
Did crunch and jumble in the glade;
The Quibblefix, so indiscreet,
Came meddling through the shade.

"Beware its pokey-prodding ways!
The claws that pinch, the tongue that pries,
It tangles all your working days
With snoopered-snooping lies!"

The chaos-beast slipped left and right,
Through papers, plans, and peaceful thought,
Till nothing stayed where it was quite,
And order came to naught.

Then whoosh! and whisk! and whirl around!
The Quibblefix did dance and spin,
Till every settled thing it found
Was mixed and muddled in.

'Twas snazzling, and the whimblefeet
Lay scattered by its merry raid;
The Quibblefix, its work complete,
Skipped grinning through the glade.

poem:
The Slithersqueeze

'Beware the Slithersqueeze, my pet,
With tentacreeps that slyly wind,
Its squishling steps will make you fret,
As shadows lurk behind!'

Through murbled halls and spongy floors,
The creepling oozed its way,
With slurping slips through closing doors,
In search of prey to sway.

I took my vorpal mop in hand,
And swept with mighty swish!
The creepstuff fled across the land,
Like scattered drops of fish.

'O frabjous day! The creep is gone!'
I chortled in my glee.
'The Slithersqueeze has slunk withdrawn,
And left our chambers free!'

poem:
The Burbling Awl

Through whimpled woods, where snazzles play,
The burbling awl did snick and sway,
With pointéd nose so sharp and bright,
It pierced the gloaming twilifright.

A monstrous Grimplethorn did spy
The awl's sweet dance beneath the sky,
And thought to snatch it for its lair,
But slipped upon its footsteps rare.

So round and round they twistled there,
The awl's steel glinting everywhere,
Till Grimplethorn, quite spun about,
Did wibble home in dizzy rout.

Now safe at last, the awl does keep
Its spiraled dance while monsters sleep,
And in the whimpled woods so fair,
Still snazzles watch it pirling there.

poem:
The Perils of Layover Bay

'Twas gloaming in the terminy halls
Where travelers whiffled to and fro,
The lugglings dragged against the walls
While schedules mumbled: "No, no, no."

"Beware the Layover Bay, my friend!
The gates that switch, the flights that flee!
Beware the Cancelwock, and tend
Your boarding pass most carefully!"

They took their vorpal phones in hand,
Long time the next flight they did seek—
So rested they by coffee stand,
And stood awhile to speak.

And as in terminal-ish thought they stood,
The Cancelwock, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the terminal wood,
Delay-forms dancing just the same!

One, two! One, two! Their tickets through!
The vorpal phones went snicker-snack!
They found their flight, and with their crew,
They went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Cancelwock?
Come to thy home, O weary one!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
The layover was done!

To find its swifter, simpler way.

All pad along its swooping trail,
Through splunkish mud and morning smoke,

poem:
The Sciencewock Fair

Beware, young minds, the sciencewock fair,
Where glippy projects fume and flare!
All mimsy were the voltiplates,
And hypothesis relates.

"Beware the Judgerwock, my son!
The clipboards fierce, the pencils run!
Beware the data-bird, and shun
The chemical rerun!"

He took his graphing sword in hand;
Long time the maths-some foe he planned—
Then rested by the bunsen tree
And stood awhile in glee.

And as in labcoat thought he stood,
The Judgerwock, with eyes of wood,
Came whiffling through the poster-board,
And scritched while it explored!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
His research proved both sound and true!
The ribbon blue he did exclaim,
And chortled in his fame!

"And hast thou won the science fair?
Come to my arms, my beamish heir!
O frabjous day! Results, hurray!"
He brigged in his display.

'Twas brilliant, and the slidey votes
Did gyre and gimble on their notes:
All mimsy were the voltiplates,
And hypothesis relates.

poem:
The Mistlegrump

'Twas glimming in the pearlish dawn
When mistlings swirled and wisped about,
The Mistlegrump came creeping on
With smokeish fins and vapored snout.

All swoozily the world did fade
In graysome waves of morning-murk,
While tree-tops through the foggish shade
Did twist and glumpily lurk.

The mist-breath coiled round branch and stone,
All whiffling in the pearled air,
Till naught was clear to call one's own
And ghostlings danced without a care.

Then sunbeams broke the moisty spell,
The Mistlegrump did fade away,
And all that was so strange and fell
Turned bright into the common day.

The Meetingmost Beast

Beware the conference room, my friend,
Where gloptious screens do glow and bend,
Where slideshows lurk and charts descend—
The meetingmost ahead!

Take up thy laptop, badge in hand,
Through glass-walled chambers, stark and bland,
Where slithy colleagues understand
The dreadpost that we spread.

The whiteboard markers, fresh and clean,
The coffee pods, so nicely seen,
The chairwheels spinning oft between
The tablelegs with dread.

But lo! The meeting's done at last!
The action items tumbling past,
The deadlines set, decisions cast—
"Success!" the team all said.

And fripjous day! We're free to go,
Back to our desks in gentle flow,
Till calendar alerts do show
More meetings straight ahead!

The Third-Rail Thrummox

'Twas sparkling bright, the chizzled track
Where glimmerodes in copper shone,
All zestly were the currents back
Where Thrummox made its drone.

"Beware the buzz-hum, dearest child!
The jolts that spark, the shocks that zing!
Beware the crackling, running wild,
And every buzzing thing!"

He took his voltage stick in hand,
Long time the railway foe he sought—
Then rested by the third-rail stand,
In deep electric thought.

And as in ohmic thought he stood,
The Thrummox, with its fuzzing gleam,
Came whiffling through the steely wood,
All sizzlewick with steam!

One-two! One-two! Through split and shake
The current-dance went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its wake
He galvanized back.

"And hast thou slain the humming beast?
Come ride the rails, my sparkish boy!
O wondrous day! O power ceased!"
He flickered in his joy.

'Twas sparkling bright, the chizzled track
Where glimmerodes in copper shone,
All zestly were the currents back
Where silence found its home.

The Grindergroan

Through misted pillars, dank and drear,
The plipsome echoes slith and veer,
While Munglethumps with clacking feet
Make spluncherous sounds beneath the street.

The concrete walls, all grimy-grey,
Where whisperations bounce and play,
Send back each footstep, cough and call
In mirrorspeak along the wall.

The passing cars above do roar,
Their rumblestumps sink through the floor,
Till Munglethumps, in woeful fright,
Scutch deeper in the endless night.

While dampness makes the droplets ring,
And there beneath the city's weight,
The soundlings dance and duplicate.

poem:
The Printerbeast's Lament

'Twas printy and the pageful tray
Did whirr and grumble in its space.
All flibbered were the sheets that day,
When paper jams took place.

"Beware the Printerbeast, my friend!
The teeth that grab, the rolls that catch!
Beware the Crumplejam, and then
The Munchergears that snatch!"

He took his screwgled tool in hand,
Long time the mangled foe he sought—
Then rested by the toner stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in frustered rage he stood,
The Printerbeast, with lights of red,
Came grinking through the metal hood,
Still chomping as it fed!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The mighty fingers reached inside!
He pulled the crumpled sheets anew,
And freed them with pride!

"And hast thou slain the Printerbeast?
Come print thy pages, working well!
O frabjous day! The jam has ceased!"
He smiled as papers fell.

'Twas printy and the pageful tray
Did whirr and purr all smooth in place.
All perfect were the sheets that day,
Emerging now with grace.

poem:
The Whimbleflit's Return

'Twas glimrick, and the swoozling haze
Did drift and wamble through my mind;
All mimsy were the haunted days,
The future-past entwined.

The Whimbleflit, with eyes aglow,
Came spinning through the misty scene—
I'd sworn I'd seen it long ago,
Or had it yet to be?

Each step I took, each word I spoke,
Each turn around the bending stair,
Like memories that time awoke
That weren't yet written there.

The moments loop, the world repeats,
In spirals strange and whorling true;
Along familiar-foreign streets
The Whimbleflit slips through.

'Twas glimrick, and the swoozling haze
Still drifts and wambles in my head;
These twice-lived moments, double-days,
Both coming and long-fled.

Make splendiferous sounds alone.

The harmony came flowing back!
O frabjous tunes! Hip hip hooray!
The music room had saved the day!

Where flutlings screech and drumbles boom,
All mimsy were the melodays,
That symphonized in golden rays.

The Grumpful Awl

'Twas gribbly in the workshop's glare
When forth the awl did snicker-snack,
Through leather, wood and beastly fare
The Snazzlewhump did clack-a-clack.

With point so sharp and handle true,
It pierced the hides of morn and night,
Till holes appeared, both straight and new,
Where once was whole, now holey quite.

The Snazzlewhump, with teeth so keen,
Tried snatching at the shining tool,
But craftsman's hand, both swift and lean,
Made sure the beast looked quite the fool.

The awl did dance its merry pierce,
Till evening's shadows slipped away,
And workshop sounds did slowly cease.

The Crimplewock

That slinks and slithers, far and near!

Will stretch and snatch when night is come."

Through misted marsh and gloomwood tree,
The hunter bold did search with glee,
His snazzling sword held high with might,
To end the creeping thing's dark plight.

Through muddy paths and rain so sweet,
Till there! Upon a crumbled wall,
The creature did so softly crawl.

Snick-snack! The blade went whishing round!
The crimplewock fell to the ground!
"O frabjous day! The deed is done!"
The hunter cried, his battle won.

"Come home, come home, my dearest child!
No more shall crimples running wild
Disturb your sleep or haunt your way!"
And so they feasted all that day.
